prompt: Facts: On July 29, 2010, around 8:00 PM, Dilip Bapurao Donadkar (deceased) and Sunil Pandurang Nakle (PW-1, injured witness) were traveling on a motorcycle near Village Kapsi, District Yavatmal, Maharashtra.; They were stopped by four assailants: Yashodeep Bisanrao Vadode (Appellant/A1), Ram @ Ramya Bisanrao Vadode (A2, Absconding), Subhash Bisanrao Vadode (A3, Absconding), and one juvenile.; The assailants demanded money from the victims.; When Dilip Donadkar resisted, Yashodeep (A1) allegedly stabbed him in the chest with a knife.; Ram @ Ramya (A2) allegedly stabbed Sunil Nakle (PW-1) in the back.; The assailants took Rs. 500/- from the deceased's pocket and fled the scene.; PW-1 took the deceased to Rural Hospital, Ghatanji, where Dilip Donadkar was declared dead.; PW-1 lodged FIR No. 104/2010 at Ghatanji Police Station against the assailants.; Investigation included Spot Panchnama (Exh. 42), Inquest Panchnama (Exh. 44), seizure of blood-stained clothes (Exh. 45).; Post-mortem report (Exh. 38) indicated the cause of death as 'Hemorrhagic shock due to stab injury to vital organ i.e., right lung', and the injury was sufficient in the ordinary course of nature to cause death.; Yashodeep (A1) was arrested on August 1, 2010.; Pursuant to a memorandum statement by A1 (Exh. 50) under Section 27 of the Indian Evidence Act, a knife (Article A) was allegedly recovered from his house (Seizure Panchnama Exh. 51).; A Test Identification Parade (TIP) was conducted where PW-1 identified A1.; Chemical Analyzer (CA) reports confirmed human blood on A1's clothes and the recovered knife. The blood group on the knife ('B') matched the deceased's blood group.; The Trial Court (Sessions Judge, Yavatmal) convicted A1 under Sections 302, 394, 397 read with 34 IPC and Section 4/25 of the Arms Act, sentencing him to life imprisonment for murder and concurrent sentences for other offences.; The High Court of Bombay (Nagpur Bench) dismissed A1's appeal, confirming the conviction and sentence.; A1 (Yashodeep) filed the present appeal before the Supreme Court of India. | IPC: Section 34 IPC (Acts done by several persons in furtherance of common intention), Section 300 IPC (Murder - Definition used for conviction under 302), Section 302 IPC (Punishment for Murder), Section 392 IPC (Punishment for Robbery - Implicit element), Section 394 IPC (Voluntarily causing hurt in committing robbery), Section 397 IPC (Robbery, or dacoity, with attempt to cause death or grievous hurt), Section 4/25 of the Arms Act, 1959 (Punishment for possessing prohibited arms/ammunition without license)
completion: {"prosecution": [{"argument": "The testimony of the injured eyewitness (PW-1) is credible, consistent, and sufficient for conviction. Being injured lends credence to his presence and account.", "precedents": ["State of UP v. Naresh (2011) 4 SCC 324", "Jarnail Singh v. State of Punjab (2009) 9 SCC 719", "Balraje @ Trimbak v. State of Maharashtra (2010) 6 SCC 673"]}, {"argument": "Medical evidence (Post-mortem report Exh. 38) fully corroborates the ocular testimony of PW-1 regarding the nature and location of the fatal injury, establishing it as murder under Section 300 IPC.", "precedents": ["Solanki Chimanbhai Ukabhai v. State of Gujarat (1983) 2 SCC 174", "Balaji Gunthu Dhule v. State of Maharashtra (2012) 11 SCC 685", "Pruthivirajsinh Nodhubha Jadeja (D) By Lrs. vs. State Of Gujarat (2020) 16 SCC 151"]}, {"argument": "The recovery of the murder weapon (knife, Article A) at the instance of the accused (A1) under Section 27 of the Evidence Act, coupled with the CA report showing human blood matching the deceased's group ('B'), strongly implicates A1.", "precedents": ["State (NCT of Delhi) v. Navjot Sandhu @ Afsan Guru (2005) 11 SCC 600", "Praveen Kumar v. State of Karnataka (2003) 12 SCC 199", "Anter Singh v. State of Rajasthan (2004) 10 SCC 657"]}, {"argument": "Common intention under Section 34 IPC is clearly established as all four assailants acted in concert: stopping the victims, demanding money, using violence when resisted, robbing, and fleeing together.", "precedents": ["Suresh Sakharam Nangare v. State of Maharashtra (2012) 9 SCC 249", "Pandurang v. State of Hyderabad AIR 1955 SC 216", "Balraje @ Trimbak v. State of Maharashtra (2010) 6 SCC 673"]}, {"argument": "The ingredients of Section 394 (hurt during robbery) and Section 397 (use of deadly weapon during robbery causing death/hurt) are met, as A1 used a knife (deadly weapon) to cause the fatal injury during the commission of robbery.", "precedents": ["Phool Kumar v. Delhi Administration (1975) 1 SCC 797", "Ashfaq v. State (Govt. of NCT of Delhi) (2004) 3 SCC 116", "Dilawar Singh v. State of Delhi (2007) 12 SCC 641"]}], "defense": [{"argument": "Discrepancies and weaknesses in the sole eyewitness (PW-1) testimony regarding identification, sequence of events, and possibility of exaggeration under duress make it unreliable for conviction, especially for the murder charge.", "precedents": ["Hari Nath v. State of UP (1988) 1 SCC 14", "Lallu Manjhi v. State of Jharkhand (2003) 2 SCC 401", "Maya Kaur Baljeet Singh v. State of Maharashtra 2023 SCC OnLine Bom 1268"]}, {"argument": "The recovery of the knife is unreliable due to procedural flaws (e.g., potentially non-independent panch witnesses) and the inconclusive nature of the forensic evidence (common blood group 'B').", "precedents": ["Amar Singh v. State (NCT of Delhi) (2020) 19 SCC 164", "Jackaran Singh v. State of Punjab (1995) Supp 2 SCC 415", "Mohd. Arif @ Ashfaq v. State (NCT Of Delhi) (2011) 13 SCC 621"]}, {"argument": "Alternative Plea: The act causing death, while unlawful, might not constitute murder under Section 300 IPC. It could potentially fall under Section 304 Part I or II (culpable homicide not amounting to murder) if intent was primarily robbery and the stabbing occurred in a sudden fight or escalation without premeditated intent to kill.", "precedents": ["Virsa Singh v. State of Punjab AIR 1958 SC 465", "Rampal Singh v. State of UP (2012) 8 SCC 289", "Surinder Kumar v. Union Territory, Chandigarh (1989) 2 SCC 217"]}]}
